intro: Welcome, budding scientists! Let's explore how heat likes to move around. Imagine two objects, like a warm cup of water and your hand. What do you think happens to the heat?

questions.question: When you place a hot object (Object A) next to a cold object (Object B), how does the heat energy move?
options: Heat moves from Object A to Object B.
Heat moves from Object B to Object A.
Heat moves back and forth equally.
questions.hint: Think about what happens when you touch something hot. Does your hand get hotter or colder?

questions.question: If Object A is at 70°C and Object B is at 20°C, in which direction will heat flow?
options: Heat will flow in both directions at the same rate
questions.hint: Heat always flows from a higher temperature to a lower temperature.

questions.question: What happens to the temperature of Object B if it is colder than Object A and heat is flowing from A to B?
options: The temperature of Object B will increase.
The temperature of Object B will decrease.
The temperature of Object B will stay the same.
The temperature of Object B will fluctuate.
questions.hint: If heat is added to an object, what usually happens to its temperature?

followups: Great job observing how heat moves! This principle of heat flowing from hot to cold is super important.
Remember, heat is a form of energy, and it always seeks to spread out from where it's concentrated to where it's less concentrated.
summary: Heat always travels from a hotter object to a colder object until they reach the same temperature.
